### Getting started

Let $r$ stand for the radius of the circle. There are three possible cases:

1.  Point $H$ lies inside the circle if $NH< r$.

2. Point $H$ lies on the circle if $NH= r$.

3. Point $H$ lies outside the circle if $NH> r$ .

### Finding the radius

Let's sketch the point $E(-1,1)$ that lies on the circle and the center of the circle $N(-6,-2)$. The distance between these two points is the radius $(r)$ of the circle.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/256151125939d4137649ba42da5d6ae6fa56bf29)

Using the Pythagorean theorem (or distance formula), we have:

$\qquad\begin{align}
(r)^2&=\redD{5}^2+\redD{3}^2 &&\text{Pythagorean theorem} \\[2ex]
r&=\sqrt{\redD{5}^2+\redD{3}^2} &&\text{Square root both sides} \\[1.5ex]
&=\goldD{\sqrt{34}} \\[1.5ex]
\end{align}$

So the radius of the circle is $\goldD{\sqrt{34}}$.

### Find the length $NH$

The length $NH$ is the distance between the center of the circle $N$ and point $H$.

Now let's sketch the point $H(-10,-7)$ and use the Pythagorean theorem (or distance formula) to find $NH$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1be106a0c5c3de68006798f48376795fb1bc1a3a)

$\qquad\begin{align}
(NH)^2&=\redD{4}^2+\redD{5}^2 &&\text{Pythagorean theorem} \\[2ex]
NH&=\sqrt{\redD{4}^2+\redD{5}^2} &&\text{Square root both sides} \\[1.5ex]
&=\sqrt{16+25} \\[1.5ex]
&=\greenD{\sqrt{41}} \\[1.5ex]
\end{align}$

### Compare $NH$ to the radius

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c02eaf3c622200fe6b9b6b9deda019cdf4fca5e6)

Point $H$ lies outside the circle because $NH>r$.

### The answer

The point $H(-10,-7)$ lies outside the circle.
